conclusion: Calculate the work done by the frictional force on the object as it moves from point M to point N.
The object experiences a gravitational force downward, F_gravity = mg, where m = 3 kg and g = 10 m/s^2.
The normal force F_normal acts upward and is equal in magnitude to the gravitational force, F_normal = mg = 30 N.
The frictional force F_friction acts opposite to the direction of motion and is given by F_friction = μF_normal = 0.3 × 30 N = 9 N.
Work done by a force is calculated using the formula W = F · d · cos(θ), where F is the force, d is the displacement, and θ is the angle between the force and the direction of displacement.
In this case, the frictional force and the displacement are in opposite directions, so θ = 180° and cos(180°) = -1.
The displacement d is the distance between points M and N, which is L_1 = 10 m.
Calculate the work done: W = F_friction · L_1 · cos(180°) = 9 N × 10 m × (-1) = -90 J.
The negative sign indicates that the work done by friction is in the opposite direction to the displacement, which is expected since friction opposes motion.
The work done by the frictional force on the object as it is transported from point M to point N is -90 J.
